Focal adhesion formation is a critical process in the cellular response to mechanical strain. Cells must first attach to the extracellular matrix in order to anchor themselves and resist the applied force. The adhesion between the cell and the matrix provides a connection that can transduce the force into biochemical signals that eventually lead to cell death or increased cell proliferation.
Inhibiting focal adhesion formation prevents the cells from attaching to the extracellular matrix and shifting into a more mechanically strained state. As a result, the cells are more likely to die from the applied force or to return to a quiescent state. In some cases, inhibiting focal adhesion formation can also lead to the production of scar tissue.

text-davinci-002_response:
"Electromagnetic interference has no effect on Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) readability and reading distances." is accurate.
RFID readers use electromagnetic waves to communicate with tags, which store information about the item to which they are attached. The reader sends out a radio signal that powers the tag and brings it to life. The tag then reflects back the signal, providing information to the reader. Because this process does not require a line of sight, RFID tags can be read even if they are hidden from view.
The main types of RFID tags are passive and active. Passive tags rely on the power from the reader to operate, while active tags have their own power source, typically a battery. Active tags typically have a longer read range than passive tags, but both types of tags can be read from a distance of several feet.
EMI can interfere with the signal between the reader and the tag, causing the tag to be unreadable or the read range to be reduced. However, there are several ways to mitigate the effects of EMI, such as using shielded cables or enclosures, using frequency-hopping technology, or placing the tag and reader in a Faraday cage.
In conclusion, the claim that "Electromagnetic interference has no effect on Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) readability and reading distances." is accurate. While EMI can interfere with the signal between the reader and the tag, there are several ways to mitigate its effects.
